skill.name: codebase-mapping
skill.description: Repository structure and dependency analysis for understanding a codebase's architecture. Use when needing to (1) generate a file tree or structure map, (2) analyze import/dependency graphs, (3) identify entry points and module boundaries, (4) understand the overall layout of an unfamiliar codebase, or (5) prepare for deeper architectural analysis.

security_audit.summary: Static scanner generated false positives due to pattern matching without semantic understanding. The skill only reads files within a specified directory to analyze code structure, excludes build/cache directories, and outputs JSON results. No network calls, code execution, or credential access detected. A prior audit (2026-01-10) correctly assessed this as low risk.

low_findings.title: Broad filesystem access within target directory
low_findings.description: The script recursively reads files in the target repository for analysis. Necessary for codebase mapping. Excludes node_modules, .git, __pycache__, and other build directories.

content.value_statement: Understanding unfamiliar codebases is time-consuming and error-prone. This skill generates comprehensive maps of repository structure, dependency graphs, and entry points to accelerate your analysis.
actual_capabilities: Generates annotated file trees excluding build artifacts like node_modules
Extracts import dependencies from Python and JavaScript/TypeScript files
Identifies entry points like main.py, app.py, setup.py, and package.json
Maps internal module dependencies and external package imports
Categorizes key files by type: schemas, execution, tools, agents, config
limitations: Only analyzes Python and JavaScript/TypeScript files
Cannot resolve dynamic imports or runtime-only dependencies
Requires local filesystem access to target repository
May miss entry points in complex monorepo structures

use_cases.title: Analyze Legacy System Architecture
use_cases.description: Map a legacy codebase to understand module boundaries and create a modernization plan

use_cases.title: Navigate New Codebase Quickly
use_cases.description: Get oriented in an unfamiliar repository by identifying key files and dependencies

use_cases.title: Document Code Architecture
use_cases.description: Generate structured documentation of codebase organization for team reference

prompt_templates.title: Dependency Analysis

prompt_templates.prompt: Identify all executable entry points in this codebase and their purposes

best_practices: Exclude build directories and dependencies from analysis to focus on source code
Use the generated key files list to prioritize which modules to examine first
Combine with other analysis skills for deeper architectural insights
anti_patterns: Analyzing node_modules or vendor directories will produce noise and slow analysis
Running on production codebases without understanding the output format first
Assuming all entry points are automatically detected - manual verification needed

faq.question: Which file types does this skill analyze?
faq.answer: Currently supports Python (.py) and JavaScript/TypeScript (.js, .ts, .jsx, .tsx) files

faq.question: How does it handle large repositories?
faq.answer: The skill limits directory traversal depth and excludes common build/cache directories for performance

faq.question: Can I integrate this with my CI/CD pipeline?
faq.answer: Yes, the script outputs JSON that can be parsed and used in automated workflows

faq.question: Is my code safe? Does it send data externally?
faq.answer: All analysis happens locally. No code or metadata is transmitted outside your system

faq.question: What if it misses some dependencies?
faq.answer: Dynamic imports and runtime-only dependencies may not be detected. Use static analysis results as a starting point

faq.question: How is this different from standard tree commands?
faq.answer: Beyond file structure, it analyzes imports, identifies entry points, and builds dependency graphs
